bstools module¶

Created on Mon Nov 12 14:02:38 2018

@author: clemonnier

bstools.are_anagrams(s1, s2)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • s1 (str) – string of characters (could be a word or a set of words separated by delimiters)
  • s2 (str) – string of characters (could be a word or a set of words separated by delimiters)
Returns:

True is s1 and s2 are anagrams, False if they are not
Return type:

bool
Example: 
>>> import bstools
>>> bstools.are_anagrams("Elections results","Lies let's recount")
True

Note

This function is not case-sensitive and does not take delimeters and punctuation into account (cf Example)

bstools.char_freq(s, cs=True)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • s (str) – string of characters (could be a word or a set of words separated by delimiters)
  • cs (bool) – Indicates if whether or not case should be taken into account.
Returns:

associative array giving the number of occurrences of each character in s
Return type:

dict
Example: 
>>> import bstools
>>> a = "Kiwi"
>>> bstools.char_freq(a)
{'K': 1, 'i': 2, 'w': 1}

Note

If s is an empty string, an empty dictionnary is returned

Warning

By default,the char_freq function is case-sensitive (cs=True). Setting cs=False allows a non-case-sensitive behaviour.

bstools.letters_only(s)[source]¶
Parameters:s (str) – string of characters (could be a word or a set of words separated by delimiters)
Returns:s without any delimiter, space, or punctuation

:rtype:str

Example: 
>>> import bstools
>>> a = "Hello World !"
>>> letters_only(a)
'HelloWorld'

…seealso:: bstools.remove(), bstools.remove_all()

bstools.remove(rm, s)[source]¶
Parameters:s (str) – string of characters (could be a word or a set of words separated by delimiters)
Returns:s without the first occurence of rm

:rtype:str

Example: 
>>> import bstools
>>> bstools.remove("na","bananas")
'banas'

…note:: The remove function is case-sensitive …seealso:: bstools.remove_all()

bstools.remove_all(rm, s)[source]¶
Parameters:s (str) – string of characters (could be a word or a set of words separated by delimiters)
Returns:s without all the possible occurences of rm

:rtype:str

Example: 
>>> import bstools
>>> bstools.remove_all("na","bananas")
'bas'

…note:: The remove function is case-sensitive …seealso:: bstools.remove()
